titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Henry Draper Image Collection MC.230
titlestmt.author: Megan Findling

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-07-19 13:32:19 -0400.

change.item: Processing note updated by John Zarrillo
Updated by Jennifer E. Neal to incorporate materials being sent to offsite storage in 2019 and for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description
Updated by John Zarrillo to include item-level description of all materials in preparation for digitization
Updated by Stacey Flatt, edited for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description, in order to published the finding aid.

did.unittitle: New York University Archives Collection of Late 19th Century Photographic Materials
did.abstract: New York University Archives Collection of Late 19th Century Photographic Materials Henry Draper was a physician and dean of faculty of the Medical Department of the University of the City of New York (now New York University). He was also a pioneer in the field of astrophotography. This collection contains many glass plates of his photographs, many of which are astronomical images. Some slides also relate to his research and teaching at the University.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Upon Henry Draper's death in 1882 a selection of items in this collection were found in his New York laboratory. Draper's sister, Mrs. Antonia Dixon, presented these items to New York University. The accession number related to this collection is 82.030.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection is arranged into ten series, arranged in chronological order within.
Series I. Henry Draper Spectra Images Series II. Henry Draper Moon Images Series III. Glass Plate Negative Fragments Series IV. Henry Draper-Related Observatories and Laboratories Images Series V. D.W. Hering X-Ray Images Series VI. NYU Campus, Students, and Related Images Series VII. Lecture Presentation Support Images Series VIII. Daguerreotypes Series IX. Document Reproductions, Memorial Images Series X. Original Storage Housing

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Henry Draper was born March 7, 1837, to John William Draper and Antonia Coetana de Paiva Pereira Gardner. John William Draper was a doctor, chemist, and professor at the University of the City of New York (now New York University), and his son Henry followed closely in his footsteps. Henry Draper graduated from the Medical Department of the University of the City of New York in 1857. He became a physician at Bellevue Hospital and later returned to the University as a professor and eventually as dean of faculty of the Medical Department. Despite his employment as a doctor, Draper also spent a large amount of time on his passion of astrophotography. He even built his own observatory on his father's estate at Hastings-on-Hudson. Draper was a pioneer in the astrophotography field, directing an expedition to photograph the 1874 transit of Venus and being the first to photograph an astronomical nebula with his image of the Orion Nebula in 1880. He was also interested in spectra, taking the first image of the stellar spectrum in 1872. Draper also invented the slit spectrograph and improved on many photographic tools such as telescope clock drives which are necessary to steady long photographic exposures.

In 1867 Henry Draper married the wealthy socialite Anna Mary Palmer. Not only was she an able laboratory assistant, but she also helped turn their home into a center for celebrities and scientists. Draper was well recognized, receiving honorary law degrees from the University of the City of New York and the University of Wisconsin, a Congressional medal, and election to both the National Academy of Sciences and the Astronomische Gesellschaft. Unfortunately, Draper became ill during a trip to the Rocky Mountains and died of double pleurisy at the age of 45. His wife established the Henry Draper Memorial that awards the Henry Draper Medal for astrophysics and funded the Henry Draper Catalog, which is a massive photographic stellar spectrum survey.
Source: "Henry Draper," in Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers, ed. Thomas Hockey (New York: Springer, 2007).

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: At some point other items were pulled from an attic at a building on the NYU Heights campus and added to this collection.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Fragile materials will not be handled without the assistance of an archivist. Digital surrogates were created for all images and are available to view through this finding aid. Please contact New York University Archives with any questions regarding digital surrogates.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; New York University Archives Collection of Late 19th Century Photographic Materials; MC 230; box number; folder number or item identifier; Repository Name, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The titles assigned to each plate primarily derive from titles written on the envelopes in which the items were originally housed. It is unclear who assigned these titles and when they did so. Based on the age of the envelopes, this description was likely not in Draper's hand. Some of the items in Series I with names of specific elements are derived from titles on the actual object, and these are more likely to have been written by Draper himself. Untitled items were given the same title as the series in which they are found.

This collection was originally described by T.J. Herczeg (University of Oklahoma's Department of Physics and Astronomy) and Anne Kinney (NYU's Department of Physics) for a 1982 article, "The Collection of Henry Draper Memorabilia in the New York University Archives." However, the arrangement of the collection has been altered since that date.

The glass covers of the daguerreotypes were replaced by the National Museum of American History (NMAH) in 1987. In March 2017, one of the original glass covers was discovered by the NMAH staff. This was returned to the NYU Archives in November 2018 (now housed in box 10).
In 2019, a wooden cabinet that housed glass plate negatives was sent to offsite storage.

In 2023, the original title was changed from: Henry Draper Image Collection, to it's present title, to better reflect the present contents of the collection. The series titles were changed to better reflect the material within. The finding aid was edited for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of primarily glass plates of images taken by Draper and the wooden cabinet where negatives were stored. They include astrophotography images of the moon and solar spectra along with images of sites of Draper's work, such as the University campus and his observatory at Hastings-on-Hudson. Some of these glass slides have been damaged and now only exist in partial fragments. Additionally, this collection contains Draper's collection of lantern slides of historical images and reproductions of his photographs used in educational presentations.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Henry Draper are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from York University Archives, 212-998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open without restrictions, but extremely fragile. It is recommended to use the digital surragates of these images.

did.unittitle: Series I. Henry Draper Spectra Images

physdesc.physfacet: Glass plate; Small label is only partially legible: Aug 11th, 187-, 6 PM, 10th.
Collodion Wet Negative, Glass plate; Small sticker label: Aug 12, 1873, Midday 5 5.
Collodion process wet plate, glass negative; possible evidence of mold.

Narrower than the other plates in collection and appears to be a slightly different photographic process. Wet plate, glass negative; Label: difficult to decipher. The number 4/12 appears between two words or abbreviations. Dated 19 June 76.

did.unittitle: Print of Solar Spectrum -- Discovery of Oxygen in the Sun

daodesc.p: Print of solar spectrum-"Discovery of oxygen in the sun" (2): 1876-

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Upper part of photograph is spectrum of sun. Lower part is spectrum of oxygen and nitrogen of air. This is the illustration (probably the original for the reproduction) in the paper about oxygen in the sun (J. Franklin Institute vol. 74).

did.unittitle: Spectra of Beta Persei and Beta Lyrae

dao.xlink:title: Spectra of Beta Persei and Beta Lyrae (28)

daodesc.p: Spectra of Beta Persei and Beta Lyrae (28): undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sample sent to Mrs. Draper December 12 1897. Spectra of Beta Persei and Beta Lyrae at full light time and at minimum. The difference in width of the lines. The disappearance of 1 line at minimum and the overlapping of the ends of the spectra may be real phenomena and require further study. A number of plates taken last night will probably settle these points. The other spectra represent the variables Beta Lyrae and Omicron Ceti. The differences in these types of variables is well shown by these spectra. One prism (?) enlarged three times.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a Daguerreotype portrait of NYU alumnus, writer Cornelias Mathews; unknown object; 24 blank Daguerreotype sheets; and a glass cover.

did.unittitle: Series IX. Document Reproductions, Memorial Images

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes images of the Henry Draper Memorial, a portrait of John Johnson, an insect, and reproductions of images of unknown documents.
